timeline.body: javadoc : `Get a list of read-only credentials sequentially `  ? Since it is `unmodifiableList`

timeline.author: hemanttanwar

timeline.body: Should we move this up to ChainedTokenCredential? That way users who created a CTC can continue to extract the list for further modification.
timeline.bodyText: Should we move this up to ChainedTokenCredential? That way users who created a CTC can continue to extract the list for further modification.
timeline.bodyHTML: Should we move this up to ChainedTokenCredential? That way users who created a CTC can continue to extract the list for further modification.
timeline.author: jianghaolu

replies.bodyText:
I think not,
as that will allow users to alter the behavior of an already instantiated credential.
It might be fine, if we return back a copy.
But, this is not applied towards all languages as per the proposal.
replies.author: g2vinay

timeline.body: Why returning an unmodifiable list here? I thought the intention of this API is return a copy of the current list for the user to modify before creating a CTC out of it.
timeline.bodyText: Why returning an unmodifiable list here? I thought the intention of this API is return a copy of the current list for the user to modify before creating a CTC out of it.
timeline.bodyHTML: Why returning an unmodifiable list here? I thought the intention of this API is return a copy of the current list for the user to modify before creating a CTC out of it.
timeline.author: jianghaolu

replies.bodyText:
I think @schaabs said, we either return immutable list or a copy of it.
I think having it immutable prevents the use of indexes to replace/re-order items in place. and will require users to create their custom list whenever they want to modify it.
We can return a copy too.
replies.author: g2vinay

timeline.body: This should return an unmodifiable list. Create the unmodifiable list in the ctor itself.
timeline.bodyText: This should return an unmodifiable list. Create the unmodifiable list in the ctor itself.
timeline.bodyHTML: This should return an unmodifiable list. Create the unmodifiable list in the ctor itself.
timeline.author: srnagar

replies.author: g2vinay

timeline.body:
ArrayList has a ctor that allows you to pass a collection directly.
```suggestion
        this.tokenCredentials = new ArrayList<TokenCredential>(tokenCredentials);
```
timeline.bodyHTML:
ArrayList has a ctor that allows you to pass a collection directly.

Suggested change
this.tokenCredentials = new ArrayList<TokenCredential>(tokenCredentials.size());
this.tokenCredentials.addAll(tokenCredentials);
this.tokenCredentials = new ArrayList<TokenCredential>(tokenCredentials);
timeline.author: srnagar

timeline.body: The description here says that the list is read-only is this the case? It's returning the underlying instance of `credentials` as a `List<TokenCredential>`? We want to make sure we don't allow people to mutate the state of the already created credential.
timeline.bodyText: The description here says that the list is read-only is this the case? It's returning the underlying instance of credentials as a List<TokenCredential>? We want to make sure we don't allow people to mutate the state of the already created credential.
timeline.bodyHTML: The description here says that the list is read-only is this the case? It's returning the underlying instance of credentials as a List<TokenCredential>? We want to make sure we don't allow people to mutate the state of the already created credential.
timeline.author: schaabs

replies.bodyText: Discussed this offline, and since we're using Colletions.unmodifiableList to create this instance we can return it without worrying about users modifying it.
replies.author: schaabs
